text: [music playing]

- Young entrepreneur
Fabio Lavelanet

is leading the way in
trying to get Liberians
to eat more homegrown rice.
[music playing]

He started the country's
first commercial-scale

rice-processing
facility, Fabrar Liberia.

FABIO LAVELANET: What we do
is we go out to these farmers

and we purchase the
rice that they grow.

We looked at it as a way
to, one, create jobs,

support livelihoods
for farmers in Liberia,

but also as a way for Liberia to
be self-sustaining when it came
to producing a staple food.

- Rice is a huge part
of the Liberian diet,
so the demand is there.

MOSES ZINNAH: We are
by far the largest
rice eaters in our sub-region.

We eat over 100 kilograms of
mill rice per person per year.

That's a lot of rice compared to
Senegal, Ghana, and the others.

- Rice has also played a major
role in Liberia's history.

In 1979, a price
hike on imported rice

was one of the factors that
led to the country's civil war.

Today, after more than
a decade of stability,

Africa's oldest republic still
imports most of its rice,
mainly from Asia and the US.

It costs the country up
to $200 million a year.

MOSES ZINNAH: We bring
in close to 300,000
metric tons per year.

Our demand is around
400,000 to 450,000.

- Fabrar Liberia is growing
at a slow but steady pace.

As they introduce large-scale
processing techniques,

they hope Liberians will
accept locally-produced rice
over imports.

FABIO LAVELANET:
When we started,
we were very, very small.

We were niche
marketing at the time.

We started with a
one-ton per day mill.

And now, we're doing
about 150 tons a month.

Things have moved from a very
base state where we started

seven years ago to now
progressing where you see

farmers actually treating
rice as a business

and investing into their farms,
and looking at it as something
that's commercially viable.

- One of his steady
suppliers is located
in the unlikeliest of places.

Tucked away in Monrovia's
bustling suburb of Paynesville

is the Community Hope
Agriculture Project, or CHAP.

It's headed by Robert
Bimba, a pastor

who is also bent on changing
lives through farming.

ROBERT BIMBA: It's better
to grow your own food
and eat what you grow.

And next is more dignified when
people work for their own money
than people giving them money.

- Through a
partnership with Japan,

the Liberian
government has given

CHAP access to 1800 hectares
of lowland to cultivate.

ROBERT BIMBA: In 2008, this
place was a criminal hideout.
This is in [inaudible] Monrovia.

Business was [inaudible], and
criminals were giving people
a hard time in the community.
So, we saw the need.

- That criminal hideout has
been turned into rich farmland,

growing mostly rice, seed rice
for planting and mill rice
for eating.

MOSES ZINNAH: We just
harvested, and now
we are planting our new rice.

And now, we introduce a system
of rice intensification,

where it's a
climate-smart approach,

where you plant less
rice and get more
than you can use all seasons.

And it's providing a
lot of hope for people.

- Many farmers complain
that the government

subsidizes rice imports,
but doesn't offer
subsidies for growing rice.

The Ministry of Agriculture
said it plans to start offering

seeds and fertilizer with
help from the African
Development Bank.

The government is also
addressing other concerns.

MOSES ZINNAH: Our
biggest challenge
really is infrastructure.

As I go around the country, even
though we estimate that we are

producing around 40% to
50% of our rice needs,

we have a lot in the villages
and towns who don't have access

to roads to be able
to truck the rice out

of the hands of the
farmers to process,
to package, and to sell.

FABIO LAVELANET: So, this
is one of the types of rice
that we mill here at Fabrar.

This is red country rice,
as it's affectionately
known in Liberia.
[music playing]

- And now, homegrown
rice has become a lot
more visible in local markets.

This makes Lavelanet
optimistic about the future.

FABIO LAVELANET: Just looking
at where we started from

and where we are now,
and seeing, you know,

some of the things that
are coming up around us

with other millers now
getting into the industry,

and seeing that, you
know, more attention

is being paid to
local production,

I think that that's
something to be proud of.
I mean, we are pioneers.

I feel like we're
pioneers in doing that.
And you know, that's great.
[music playing]

- And he hopes
others will join him

in his goal towards
self-sufficiency
in his country.
